field_reports.description:
Tropical Storm Sara, has significantly impacted Belize, with effects seen across multiple districts. The storm brought heavy rainfall of 6 to 18 inches in various areas. Severe flooding occurred along major rivers, including the Macal, Mopan, Rio Hondo, and Belize Rivers, with downstream communities in the Cayo and Belize Districts most affected. Flash flood alerts remain active, and landslides have been reported on the Maya Mountain slopes.

Several roads and bridges were rendered impassable, particularly in northern and central regions, including the San Roman and San Antonio roads in Orange Walk and parts of the Coastal and Hummingbird Highways. Urban flooding in Belize City and surrounding areas has disrupted daily life, while low-lying communities in southern Belize experienced strong winds and damage from storm surges of up to 3 feet.

Approximately 30% of the population has been directly impacted. The National Emergency Management Organization (NEMO) has coordinated disaster responses, evacuation, opening emergency shelters in various districts and advising continued vigilance. Communities are urged to prepare for prolonged recovery efforts as floodwaters recede.

field_reports.description: Tropical Storm Sara is currently positioned approximately 205 miles east-southeast of Belize City, moving westward with sustained winds of 50 mph. Forecasted to intensify, Sara could reach Category 1 hurricane strength as it approaches the coast of Belize on Sunday. The most vulnerable areas include the Central and Northern Regions, specifically near the Rio Hondo, Macal, Mopan, and Belize Rivers, where flood warnings are in effect due to saturated grounds from previous storms. The storm brings the risk of 5-10 inches of rainfall, which could lead to life-threatening flash floods and landslides, especially on roads like San Roman and San Antonio in the Orange Walk District. Coastal regions may experience minor to moderate coastal flooding, with waves impacting areas where Sara makes landfall.

field_reports.description: Tropical Depression TD 19 is forecasted to intensify to Tropical Storm or even Category 1 Hurricane Sara by Sunday, November 17, potentially impacting Belize with winds up to 140 km/h and heavy rains. Belize, already saturated from Tropical Storm Nadine, which has caused significant flooding faces heightened risks of flash floods and widespread flooding, especially with additional surges expected from Honduras. NEMO has issued a national advisory, activated standby protocols, and is preparing the Emergency Operations Center in Ladyville. Residents are urged to finalize emergency plans and follow NEMO’s updates as the storm approaches. Those in flood-prone areas are advised to stay prepared for possible evacuations. At present it is uncertain which part of the country will be affected but the entire country is expected to receive heavy rains. Presently NEMI is responding to localized floods in the north, central and south of the country

field_reports.description:
Corozal District:  Communities like San Roman, Santa Cruz, San Antonio, and Douglas are at risk due to continued rising flood levels along the Rio Hondo. San Roman’s access road is already impassable.

Orange Walk District: Hill Bank and Tower Hill are expected to experience increasing water levels, while above-normal levels are anticipated at Caledonia.

Cayo District: Flood levels at Benque Viejo on the Mopan River are expected to approach Hurricane Keith levels. San Ignacio has surpassed flood stages, affecting the low-lying bridge.

Belize District: The Crooked Tree Lagoon is approaching bankfull levels, and on the Sibun River at Freetown Sibun, flood stages are imminent.

Toledo District: Rising flood levels are expected at San Pedro Columbia and Big Falls on the Rio Grande, and above-normal levels are anticipated at Medina Bank on the Deep River.

These conditions pose risks of property damage, restricted mobility, and threats to community safety, particularly in flood-prone and low-lying area.

field_reports.description:
Tropical Storm conditions associated with Nadine are spreading over coastal pats of the Corozal, Belize and Stann Creek Districts. The National Meteorological Service's weather station at Half Moon Caye recently reported a wind gust of 43 mph. A general westward motion with an increase in forward speed is expected for the remainder of Saturday, October 19th, 2024, before the tropical storm makes landfall along the coast of Belize in a few hours. No significant strengthening is expected before the system makes landfall.

The main threat from Tropical Storm Nadine is heavy rainfall. Rainfall totals of 1 to 2 inches have already been recorded and an additional 4 to 6 inches are possible, especially over northern and central Belize. This could result in flooding.

Winds of 50 miles per hour with higher gusts will occur within the impact area. This may result in damage to weak structures, crops, and trees.

A minor storm surge generally less than 1 foot is possible just north of where the system makes landfall.

field_reports.description:
07/02/24- Hurricane Beryl is currently moving west-northwestward across the southeastern Caribbean Sea and is expected to reach the northwestern Caribbean Sea by Thursday. Belize may start feeling the effects of the storm on Thursday night. As of now, Hurricane Beryl is a Category 5 hurricane in the Caribbean Sea. 

There is a high-pressure system expected to force the hurricane on a more westward track. However, there is significant uncertainty regarding the projected area of landfall, with possible impacts ranging from southern Belize to the northern Yucatán Peninsula. The strongest concentration of projected landfall is estimated in northern Belize.

Northern Belize is already experiencing flooding due to previous rains, which could exacerbate the impact of Hurricane Beryl.

This hurricane marks a historic event as the first major hurricane in June during what is expected to be an above-average active season. 

Today, further evaluations will provide a clearer picture of whether Belize will be directly impacted by the system. 

Ronald Gordon, Chief MET Officer, stated: "There is a high level of uncertainty, so we cannot precisely predict the landfall at this time."

07/04/24 - NEMO released a fifth advisory informing the general public that at 3:00 a.m. (local time) Hurricane Beryl was located near latitude 18.5N, longitude 81.0W, or about 485 miles east of Corozal Town. Beryl was moving to the west-northwest at 20 mph with maximum sustained winds of 120 mph. A west to west-northwestward motion is expected today until the hurricane makes landfall on the Yucatan Peninsula of Mexico later tonight into early Friday morning. Although a direct landfall on Belize is unlikely, this system is likely to produce moderate to heavy rainfall across Belize starting today and continuing through the next 24 to 36 hours. Rainfall totals of 4 to 6 inches are possible with locally higher amounts, especially over the northern districts. This may lead to flooding over low-lying and flood prone areas given that soils in the area are already saturated. Gusty winds to tropical storm force are possible in the extreme north of the country as the system makes landfall later tonight into Friday morning. Strong thunderstorms accompanied by gusty winds and squally conditions are also possible in feeder bands over other areas of the country. Sea conditions are expected to become rough. A Tropical Storm Watch remains in effect from Belize City to Corozal, including the islands of Ambergris Caye and Caye Caulker the forecast shows the affected areas might be the northern coastal communities (Corozal Town, Consejo, Fireburn, Sarteneja, Copper Bank, Chunox, among others). All businesses and offices have been advised to remain open tonight.

field_reports.description:
The initial situation overview right now is approximately 200 families, totaling around 800 persons were impacted by these fires spread across 19 communities and 600 acres in the Toledo district. The Mountain Pine Ridge reserve, and the Elijio Panti National Park, are facing severe forest fires that are currently affecting the District of Toledo and the air quality of the Cayo District. The forest fires have been raging in the mountain Pine Ridge area for about three weeks. Twenty-four (24) villages/communities primarily in the wesern portion of Toledo were impacted (Aguacate, Bladen, Big Falls, Blue Creek, Corazon Cree, Crique Jute, Dolores, Eldridgeville, Golden Stream, Jordan, Laguna, Mabil Ha, Mafredi, Theresa, Sundaywood, Silver Creek, San Antonio (Toledo) and Trio), with secondary impact to residents due to smoke/poor air quality which resulted in various respiratory conditions and the suspension of classes earlier this week. Livestock impacted includes chicks, chicken, turkey and ducks. Over 50 different fruits were impacted. The government has mobilized volunteers and defense forces to assist with containing the fire. The main effects in the Toledo were loss of livelihoods and crops, temporary displacement, and respiratory health issues. the main effects in the Cayo District to date are loss of pine forest and smoke propagation throughout the district, impacting many communities for several days. Preliminary impacts in the Cayo District are: the Mountain Pine Ridge area has 9,098.4 hectares of farm land have been destroyed. So far there have been 91 reported cases of respiratory illnesses. Of the farms that were accessible, approximately six hundred (600) acres of agricultural crops and livestock were lost. Once accessible, the remaining villages will be assessed for damages/loss. The environment impact is yet to be determined. The Belize Red Cross supported the response in Toledo with 160 cooked meals for the community volunteers and the Belize Defense Force who are assisting with the Fire. Multiple agencies are coming together to provide meals and other relief items. Focus is on trying to contain fires and providing psychosocial support to the families affected.

6/6/24:

Continuous high temperatures and low rainfall across the Belize increased the liklihood of more fires across the country.

Toledo District: localized fires developed near the San Pedro Colombia village, and has increased significantly in central and southern Toledo. Four hundred (400) families have been impacted by the loss of their livelihoods, subsistence crops in twenty-eight (28) communities. There has also been much environmental damage.

Cayo District: in the Mountain Pine Ridege Reserve, a lighting strie ignited a fire and it has now spread very quickly across the southern parts of the Reserve. Approximately 32,000 acres have been destroyed and farms have been lost; no numbers so far, but as assessents continue, the number will be updated.

The Mountain Pine Ridge reserve is facing severe forest fires that are currently affecting the District of Toledo and the air quality of the Cayo District. The forest fires have been raging in the mountain Pine Ridge area for about three weeks. The local government has mobilized volunteers and defense forces to assist. The Belize Red Cross was asked by NEMO to assist in distributing cooked lunches for the community volunteers and the Belize Defence Force who are assisting with the Fire. To date, we have distributed 160 plates. The farmers and residents have been affected in the remote areas. Crops such as corn, avocado, coca, pasture forests, tach, and water sources were destroyed with long term devastating effects. Multiple agencies are coming together to provide meals and other relief items. Focus is trying to contain fires and being supportive to the families affected.

field_reports.summary: BLZ: Cyclone - 2022-11 - Go report: Tropical Storm Lisa  #12 (2023-01-28)
field_reports.description: On November 2nd, Belize was faced with strong winds, heavy rains and flooding resulting from Tropical storm Lisa (Category one), 10 miles of Belize City. Major damages were caused in the Belize district with Belize City being severely impacted. Fortunately there were no deaths, however there was damage to infrastructure, roads and livestock.

Hurricane Lisa made landfall on 2nd November 2022 as a strong Category 1 storm, ten (10) miles south of Belize City at the mouth of the Sibun River in the Belize District. The storm caused major damage to the Belize District, with Belize City extensively impacted. Over 200 homes were destroyed, more than 300 structures suffered lost and/or damaged roofs, several local communities flooded, buildings, road networks and utilities infrastructure extensively damaged and some communities left inaccessible.

The Belize City Council confirms that the clean-up of the city has been completed and all debris left behind in the aftermath of Hurricane Lisa has been fully cleared. All schools have reopened. Those with additional needs stemming from damage resulting from the storm continue to receive assistance from the Government. Schools are operating at almost full capacity.

The NEMO and CEMO officials have concluded DANA (Disaster Assessment and Needs Analysis) in affected areas and have delivered relief supplies where necessary. The government had indicated that only the Standard Bearers (Area Representatives) would be on the ground providing relief. The BRC continues to liaise with NEMO and CEMO to coordinate assistance and provide support to their relief efforts by delivering aid to areas not yet covered by the agencies.

The Government this week announced that further to the DANA conducted by Government agencies, UNDP will be providing additional technical support in the form of new assessments that include the components of social and economic parameters.

Utility works are still ongoing, the national grid remains operational at 99%. BEL continues to their works on the George Price Highway and the Belize River Valley in repairing and replacing leaning electricity poles.

The BWS distribution system countrywide remains fully functional since the post-storm repairs and restoration work.

Local cable and broadband providers have reported they have completed all restoration works to their systems and have now resumed general service works and installations within the city.

The Government’s estimates that storm damages assessed to date, total BZ$250million, and that figure is on the rise.

The Government of Belize continues to receive support for Hurricane Lisa relief efforts, both monetary donations and in-kind contributions.

The Government of South Korea donated BZ$300,000 to complement the Government of Belize’s ongoing hurricane assistance to the most vulnerable families affected by the storm. The Direct Cash Transfer programme is facilitated through the Ministry of Human Development.

The storm caused major damage to the Belize District, with Belize City extensively damaged. With over 200 homes destroyed, over 300 structures suffered lost and/or damaged roofs, several local communities flooded, buildings, road networks and utilities infrastructure extensively damaged and some communities left inaccessible.

The cleanup continues across the entire city in public spaces, residential and commercial areas and in the few remaining schools that are still unable to fully recover from the storm damage and utilities loss. Most schools have now returned to in-person classes.

The Belize City Council continues to be aided in their efforts by other government agencies, charity organizations, private businesses, and citizens. The national water company, BWS, continues to assist the Belize City council with cleanup operations by facilitating the movement of debris with heavy machinery.  The city council reported that to date thirty-five (35) tons of debris were removed from the city following the passing of the storm.

The NEMO and CEMO officials remain active, both in conducting DANA (Disaster Assessment and Needs Analysis) outreach in affected areas and delivering relief. The BRC continues to liaise with NEMO and CEMO to coordinate assistance and provide support to their relief efforts by delivering aid to areas not yet covered by the agencies.

Utility works are still ongoing, the national grid remains operational at 99%. BEL continues to their works on the George Price Highway and the Belize River Valley in repairing and replacing leaning and fallen electricity poles.

The BWS distribution system countrywide remains fully functional since the post-storm repairs and restoration work, only a few customers remain without water.

Customers that remain without utility (electricity & water) services are due primarily to damaged services lines and meters caused by the storm, which are usually individual service entrance points to private property and often required a private electrician at the cost of the customer.

A flash flood warning is in effect. Shelters are available countrywide including Belize City. Key partners including the BRC have been meeting and supporting each other. Residents are advised to continue monitoring this system very closely and to follow official information coming from NEMO and the National Met Service NEMO’s has activated emergency evacuation with the BDF and an emergency hotline is 936. Situational reports from volunteers indicate that many communities countrywide are being affected by hurricane Lisa. Many homes have been destroyed and people are in need of shelter and assistance. NEMO has activated shelters and search and rescue but the influx of calls has been overwhelming, shelters are crowded and the current situation is risk to deploy first responders. Phone towers have also been down and the lost of electricity has made it difficult for people to access life-saving rescue. results.summary:
The direct impact of Hurricane Lisa comes just 2 weeks after the country experienced heavy rains and associated flooding following the passage of Tropical Storm Julia. According to NEMO, flooding as a result of tropical storm Julia affected roughly 30 communities in southern and central Belize and approximately 3,000 families had been directly or indirectly impacted.

In 2020, flooding associated with the passage of Hurricanes Eta and Iota cut off several communities, with Cayo, Stann Creek, and Belize districts being most affected. Approximately 15% of the total population in Belize was impacted. In response to these historic floods, the Belize Red Cross launched a DREF operation that targeted 5,000 people. The operation supported the distribution of household items, WASH activities and multi-purpose cash Page 3 / 18 assistance.

It should be noted that the recent impacts outlined above were not the result of a direct impact of a hydro meteorological hazard. However, hurricane Lisa directly impacted Belize and so the scale of impact can be reasonably expected to exceed these 2 previous events. Belize Red Cross (BRC) has received reports through staff, volunteers, and the National Emergency Management Office (NEMO) that several communities have been affected. Major areas impacted (hardest hit) are communities in Belize, Stann Creek and Toledo Districts as forecasted by the NEMO and Meteorological services. However there has also been some significant impacts in Cayo and Orange Districts.

Initial close estimates indicate overall 333,549 people in the country were at risk from impacts from the system. According to NEMO, at least 39% of the total population of Belize (approximately 160,000 people) was most affected by Hurricane Lisa. Only in the district of Belize, more than 90,000 people are reported to have been impacted. Among the effects, substantial damage has been reported to property. It is estimated that approximately 500 houses have been completely destroyed, while more than 5,000 houses have been partially destroyed in the Belize District. Partial damage ranged from roofs being blown off, structures being partially destroyed, ground floors being flooded and household goods being destroyed by wind and water. Initial estimates of losses to the housing sector amounts to some BZD 20 million (Approximately USD 10 million).

The Relief Supplies and Management Subcommittee of the National Emergency Management Organization (NEMO) has indicated the need to provide immediate relief to some estimated 5,000 plus families in the Belize District, and up to 1,000 families in the Stann Creek District. The estimated number of families affected in the Cayo, Orange Walk and Corozal districts can reach as much as 500 families.

Food, water, hygiene kits, bedding, cleaning supplies, tarpaulins, buckets, PPEs, power washers, construction and roofing material are the main items needed for the affected population. In addition, further damage and needs assessments (DANA) will be conducted to ensure the most appropriate provision support of affected population. Multi-Purpose Cash will be utilized as a modality for provision of support to ensure dignity, freedom of choice and facilitate livelihood reactivation where markets/business can accommodate.

It is likely to have a landfalling system but exact timing and intensity is still not too certain. System will likely produce heavy rainfall late Wednesday and Thursday with about 2 to 4 inches per day with locally higher amounts.

Calla Creek, Cayo was disconnected from the road. Bullet Tree has been impassible due to culverts that have been washed away by the flood. Cristo Rey's road was washed away as well. Infrastructure damage is estimated by government to be in the Millions.

In the west, as the Mopan River is receding where it passes Benque Viejo, Succotz, Calla Creek, Bullet Tree Falls and Paslow Falls, communities along the Sibun and Belize Rivers are experiencing flood conditions. The floodwaters are also receding as it passes through Blackman Eddy, Roaring River, La Riviera area and More Tomorrow, but are rising in the Beize River Valley pushing more floodwaters into the Belize District. It is possible that this will continue for the next 3 to 4 days and possibly longer. Residents in these areas are being advised to prepare for a possible major flood event.

Bridges and ferries that are closed are Gracie Rock Hmmock Bridge, Iguana Creek Bridge, the San Ignacio wooden bridge, the Xunantunich and the Baking Pot ferries. The Santa Familia/Branch Mouth and Calla Creek roads are now accessible after the new culverts were installed and the road repaired. The ATM Cave bridge was washed away. The Hopkins/Sittee River bypass road is impassable.

field_reports.description: Hurricane Julia hit Nicaragua on Sunday, October 9th, as a Category 1 hurricane. Belize received torrential rains during Saturday and Sunday over the entire country of Belize. The southern districts of Toledo and Stann Creek and the western district of Cayo began to experience floods on Sunday, Oct. 9th, like that in 2020 in the same districts due to Hurricane Eta and Iota. Heavy rains being dumped on neighbouring countries of Nicaragua, Honduras and Guatemala, south and west of Belize have  contributed to the rivers in Belize rising and overflowing their banks. It is expected that rivers will continue to rise during this week and next and floods will extend to the Belize District through the Belize River Valley.

results.summary:
Update from the Chief Met Office today through NEMO:
The system is now potential tropical cyclone 13. The most likely path is for the center to make landfall on Nicaragua and then move across to Honduras while weakening rapidly over the mountainous terrain. In that case it won't be a strong wind producer for Belize but will likely still produce heavy rainfall with potential flooding especially over the south. Rainfall forecast to peak on Monday with daily totals of 4 to 6 inches and locally higher amounts. Worse case, but less likely scenario, is the center moving on the northern edge of the cone. In that case Belize could be dealing with a hurricane making landfall late on Monday on the country. Will provide another update later today.

field_reports.summary: Flash Floods in South of Belize (2021-07-13)
field_reports.description: The affected area of Mafredi and Blue Creek in the Toledo District and communities along the Moho River, i.e., Aguacate, Jordan, Crique Sarco and San Vicente, are the affected by the flash floods. The latter four communities along the Moho River were inaccessible due to the submerged Blue Creek bridge being impassible. Mafredi had one large field that was completely submerged. The land is higher and thus, not totally all families were affected. Displaced families had already returned to their homes from shelters. Those who had concrete floors had already started cleaning their homes and those with dirt floors, although soaked, were throwing sand to get them dry. Most families lost a few chickens.

field_reports.summary: Flash Floods in South of Belize
field_reports.description:
Tropical wave passed over Belize on July 13-14th 2021 causing 3-4 inches of heavy rain resulting in flash floods in the Mafradi area of Toledo, southern most district of Belize. Community presently most affected is Blue creek with 50 families (250 persons). It is expected that over the next few days, the 5 villages along the Moho River will be affected, totaling 500 families starting with Auacate Village.
NEMO has requested assistance from Belize Red Cross with cleaning supplies, food, water and hygiene kits. 
Presently 60 persons are in shelters and an additional 72 persons are sheltering in private homes.
Floods are also identified in the Cayo district in the villages of Bullet Tree, Calla Creek and Billy White but of a lesser degree.

results.name: Flash Floods in South of Belize

field_reports.description:
The National Meteorological Services of Belize and NEMO reported that rainfall associated with the remnants of Hurricane Iota continues to contribute to flooding in Central areas of the country, already previously affected by Hurricane Eta.
The two major highways are open. The Low Lying Bridge in San Ignacio, Iguana Creek Bridge, and Branch Mouth Hammock Bridge remains closed. The Succotz and Baking Pot Ferry are also closed. In Belmopan the J&W and More Tomorrow areas are inaccessible. In Belize Rural the Maypen, Grace Bank and Crooked Tree villages are all inaccessible. The Macal, Mopan Rivers in the Cayo District, and the Sibun and Belize Rivers in the Belize district, continue to steadily rise. Belize River, Mount Pleasant Creek, Maya Mopan Creek and Roaring Creek are also rising in the Cayo District. In the Belize Rural area, the water levels are rising in the Crooked Tree Lagoon, Mexico Creek, and Big Falls Creek. The Rio Hondo and New Rivers in the north are rising slowly. Two hundred and thirty five (235) persons are in shelters throughout the country, primarily in the Belize Rural area (Crooked Tree, Rancho Dolores, Bermudan Landing, Burrell Boom, and Lemonal) and Cayo district (Calla Creek and Bishop Martin School), Orange walk (Trial Farm). Major relief operations are underway to assist the affected populations and cattle farmers. In the Cayo District, in Benque Viejo del Carmen, 3 high risk areas of Old Border Road Area, Arenal Village and Riverside residences further rise in river levels is anticipated as rains persist.

On November 4th, 2020 a flood warning for Central and Southern Belize was issued by the National Hydrological Service. This flood warning was in effect for rivers, streams, creeks and waterways in central and southern Belize. The National Hydrological Services has issued a flood report and forecast which indicates that in certain rivers and waterways, water levels are steadily rising above normal. On the Belize River, water levels are above normal and rising and the same is happening on the Macal and Mopan Rivers. In southern Belize, there is the minimal rise of water levels for the Sittee River at Kendal Bridge, the Swasey and Bladen branch of Money River as well as the Rio Grande in San Pedro Columbia. 
On November 5th and 6th , all of Belize is facing a national flooding event - caused by the Hurricane Eta storm system.  Eta has moved on and is now a Tropical depression heading northeast to Cuba. Fortunately, there have been no reports of loss of life, however there is plenty loss of property and damage to residences and families dislocated by the flood. The flooding started from November 4th but came on much heavier on November 5th - totally submerging San Ignacio as the Macal river was running in the streets.  The nearby villages of Bullett Tree and Calla Creek were trapped and the relevant teams were sent on rescue missions.  Also out west, the new bridge near Roaring Creek held up, but the highway approaches to it were submerged in a massive rise of the river.  
While the greatest flooding is concentrated in the west, the entire country has been affected.  NEMO reports roads that are flooded and or impassable are the Bullet Tree and Santa Familia roads, the Calla Creek road, Santa Rosa road to Calla Creek, More Tomorrow M & S road, Sittee River bypass to Hopkins, and the Coastal Road from Hope Creek to Gales Point junction. All crossings in the Cayo district are flooded or at risk to flood except the main crossings, Hawkesworth and the Santa Elena bypass (new) bridge The Cayo district has been the epicenter of the flood, however, both Belize District and Stann Creek District have been affected. 
According to NEMO, approximately 30,000 persons have been affected by this flood. There are currently 6 shelters opened countrywide with 78 persons and more persons are expected to fill these shelters as rescue missions are currently underway. The United States, Mexico and International Financial Institutions are standing by to provide assistance with food, water and shelter as needed. Тhе Вrіtіѕh Аrmу Тrаіnіng Ѕuрроrt Unіt Веlіzе (ВАТЅUВ) іѕ аѕѕіѕtіng thе Веlіzе Dеfеnсе Fоrсе wіth ѕеаrсh аnd rеѕсuе ореrаtіоnѕ. The Міnіѕtеr оf Nаtіоnаl Ѕесurіtу, Місhаеl Реуrеfіttе, ѕаіd thе ВDF аnd Соаѕt Guаrd аrе іn ореrаtіоn іn thе сеntеr аnd ѕоuth аnd hіѕ оffісе іѕ сооrdіnаtіng wіth thе vіllаgеѕ tо hеlр dіѕtrіbutе fооd аnd wаtеr, ѕubјесt tо СОVІD-19 рrоtосоlѕ.  

The Belize Red Cross has been assisting persons at the shelters and those affected by providing blankets, Tarps (shelter), Hygiene kits (IFRC) and COVID19 Hygiene Kits. BRC hopes to assist at least 1000 families countrywide with food and hygiene supplies. An assessment will be conducted to determine the extent of damages to those affected.

Cat. 4 Hurricane Eta, with winds of 150 is expected to make landfall by Tuesday evening, November 3rd in neighbouring Nicaragua, with the possibility of the hurricane being a Cat 5. Belize has started experiencing rains on and off as of today, Monday, November 2nd. Rains are expected to continue throughout the week, with heaviest rainfall on Wednesday and Thursday, November 4-5th. This is expected to cause floods in Belize, especially in the southern districts of the country, Stann Creek and Toledo. Belize will also experience some gusty winds that may cause damage, especially affecting Marine Interests. The entire country will experience a significant amount of rainfall. Total rains throughout the storm is expected between 10” -20”.

Accumulated rainfall in the hilly central and southern areas of Belize, extending northwards along the central coast will be in the order of 10-20 inches through Saturday 6:00 pm. Hurricane Iota may likely produce heavy rainfall across Belize, with rainfall activity peaking on Wednesday and Thursday, November 18-19.  Dangerous flash floods and flooding with this type of rainfall are expected, especially over mountainous areas in the south, now that soil moisture is at field capacity. A flood warning is in effect for the Belize District and a flood watch for the Toledo, Stann Creek and Cayo Districts.

field_reports.summary: Threat of TS Nana to Belize
field_reports.description: Hurricane Nana, Category 1, made landfall around midnight on September 2nd, 2020, on southern Belize, between Dangriga Town and Placencia Village in the Stann Creek District. This small hurricane in radius had hurricane winds extending 10 miles from the center. The west-southwest track took it well south of Belize City, avoiding a direct hit. Belize is now in the all clear phase. Although assessments are still ongoing, preliminary reports reaching Belize Breaking News Belize (media) is that banana and plantain farms in southern Belize have lost hundreds of acres of crops. Estimates shared are that over 800 acres from three major farms have been destroyed. There has been no loss of human life and minimal structural damage done to houses, mostly in the Stann Creek District.
